#Text=Fire Island National Seashore
#Text=Fire Island National
#Text=Seashore
#Text=is a United States National Seashore in the state of New York .
#Text=Most of the Fire Island NS is on Fire Island with one section in the hamlet of Mastic Beach in the Town of Brookhaven on Long Island .
#Text=Fire Island is a barrier island protecting Great South Bay and a portion of Long Island to its north .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Park Headquarters
#Text=M - F 9AM-4:30PM .
#Text=Not a visitor center , but brochures and information are available .
#Text=History
#Text=In the mid-17th century , Fire Island was used as a base for whaling .
#Text=Whalers would watch for spouting whales from towers , then launch their boats after them .
#Text=The island also has a bit of pirate history as pirates were known to build fires on the island to attract passing boats on which to prey .
#Text=The Fire Island Lighthouse was first built in 1826 at a height of due to the large number of shipwrecks .
#Text=In 1868 , a new lighthouse was built to a height of 168 feet , 100 feet from the old .
#Text=The foundation of the original lighthouse can still be seen today .
#Text=For many immigrants the lighthouse was their first sight of land when arriving to America .
#Text=In less than a century four miles of sand accumulated between the lighthouse and the western tip of the island .
#Text=The island still grows at its western end and is constantly reshaped .
#Text=The state set aside part of Fire Island as a state park in 1908 , making it the first state park on Long Island .
#Text=In the 1920s Fire Island began its life as a Bohemian beach community .
#Text=By the 1950s real estate was booming as the island became a fashionable retreat from the city .
#Text=In 1964 the rest of the lands were designated the Fire Island National Seashore .
#Text=In 1980 Congress set aside as the Otis Pike Wilderness area .
#Text=Landscape
#Text=All barrier islands are shaped to some degree by the ocean , and that certainly applies to Fire Island .
#Text=The Sunken Forest area is the result of high dunes built up on both sides of the trees which protect them and allow their protected growth .
#Text=Swamp species such as red maple and sour gum are then able to thrive there .
#Text=On the west end of the island new land has formed at the rate of 50 meters a year .
#Text=In some areas dunes are whipped into low cliffs in one season and the cliffs later dissolved to sloping beach .
#Text=Flora and fauna
#Text=From the unassuming insectivorous sundews lurking in swales to the tops of the wind-pruned trees in the Sunken Forest , Fire Island is a varied and most interesting barrier beach ecosystem .
#Text=This makes taking in a ranger-led interpretive program or tour a must .
#Text=The Sunken Forest area in particular is a somewhat unusual barrier island situation with several bogs , complete with sphagnum , ferns , mosses , cattails , rushes and other wetland species .
#Text=The island is also a wonderful birdwatching ( and listening ! ) venue .
#Text=Catbirds and eastern towhees keep the music playing and yellow warblers and yellow bellied sapsuckers keep it colorful .
#Text=Fire Island is a popular rest stop for migratory birds with over 300 species have been recorded here -- over one-third of the birds in North America .
#Text=There is a full array of beach dwellers as well and fishing is excellent , particularly in Great South Bay .
#Text=Climate
#Text=Fire Island has a temperate climate with expected highs in the 80s and 90s ( °F ) in summer and lows in the 20s and 30s in winter .
#Text=The park 's air temperature may be slightly cooler in summer or warmer in winter than on the mainland of Long Island .
#Text=Check the weather before leaving for Fire Island as poor weather may change ferry schedules .
#Text=Get in
#Text=Fire Island is accessible almost all year .
#Text=Most travellers visit during the summer , from May through September , when the weather is the best for beach-related activities .
#Text=At other times public transportation to the island may be limited , and some island services are unavailable .
#Text=Ferries run regularly to the island in the summer months but are limited in the off-season .
#Text=Be sure to review the train and ferry schedules in advance , and pay particular attention to the return schedules .
#Text=The Fire Island Lighthouse , William Floyd Estate , and the two parks at either end of Fire Island , Smith Point County Park and Robert Moses State Park , are accessible year-round by car .
#Text=Operating hours do vary by season .
#Text=Fire Island 's Sailors Haven , Barrett Beach/Talisman and Watch Hill areas are dependent on water travel , and are open from mid-May through mid-October each year .
#Text=The Wilderness Visitor Center is open mid-May through December .
#Text=Ranger-led interpretive activities are primarily scheduled for summer months at all locations .
#Text=By ferry
#Text=Most people get onto Fire Island by boat .
#Text=Ferries to Fire Island are passenger ferries only .
#Text=Ferries operate on a full schedule during July and August , with fewer ferries in spring and fall .
#Text=The ferry terminals on Long Island can be reached by car , bus , train , taxi or shuttle van .
#Text=Ferries to Fire Island depart from the following locations : Sayville and Bay Shore ( villages of Islip ) and Patchogue ( a village of Brookhaven ) .
#Text=Water taxis are available if you miss the ferry .
#Text=Fire Island Ferries
#Text=Bay Shore .
#Text=Year round to Ocean Beach , Fair Harbor , Dunewood , Atlantique , Kismet , Saltaire , Ocean Bay Park and Seaview .
#Text=Sayville Ferries
#Text=, 41 River Road .
#Text=Year round to Cherry Grove , Fire Island Pines , Sunken Forest and Water Island .
#Text=Patchogue Ferries
#Text=Mid March to November from two ferry terminals in Patchogue .
#Text=Leaves from County Road 83 to Davis Park ; and from County Road 19 to Watch Hill in the Fire Island National Seashore park .
#Text=By car
#Text=There are two bridges to Fire Island National Seashore .
#Text=The Robert Moses Causeway on the western end of Fire Island leads to parking lots at Robert Moses State Park .
#Text=The William Floyd Parkway leads to Smith Point County Park on the eastern end of Fire Island , where there are also parking lots .
#Text=Parking fees are charged at both lots .
#Text=There are no public roads on the island .
#Text=Park Headquarters and the William Floyd Estate are on Long Island , New York .
